ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed fundamental speaking, reading, and writing Japanese skills.
I learned how to speak Japanese at a comfortable level. Although I am not able to convey high-level concepts, I have built a strong foundation from this course.
My grasp of Japanese grammar, speaking, listening, reading, and writing improved.
I learned a lot more Japanese in speaking writing and listening, as well as kanji characters
Practiced basic Japanese language skills.
Japanese language skills
I improved my Japanese vastly

I felt like I learned so much! We picked up right where we left off in L1, and we learned even more grammar in the second semester. We covered all the basic topics of conversation/personal life, and I felt like at the end of the course I could express a wide range of emotions and ideas in Japanese.
I learned more about the Japanese language and Japanese culture, as well as becoming more confident in my conversational and reading skills.
Learned a lot more grammar constructions from new concepts and building on L1 grammar.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It is too fast-paced. I wish resources were made available to students, or at least in the future, the textbook will be available to purchase before the start of the semester to get a jump start. This semester the textbook was a pilot-version so it couldn't be helped.

I thought the course was fantastic, especially given the circumstances of COVID-19 and the requirement of virtual learning. Prof. Yamaguchi did a wonderful job of recreating the same level of conversation and active language skills practice that you would receive in a in-person language course.
The course was well-organized and lectures were engaging.

Strengths: speaking, listening, writing, all improve at a very fast pace
Weaknesses: none different from any other online seminar

You learn a ton in a short amount of time, and there's lots of support through class, clinic, and the optional language table and office hours. The classes are small and the community you form together is a great part of the course. I don't feel there's any weakness in the teaching or structure of the class, but you have to be prepared for how intense the work can be.
This course made very good use of the online format. My class was a bit large, so we didnt get as much individual attention as first semester, but I still think the class was great despite this.

A very intense language course, I found it very stressful. At times it was very fast and it's very easy to fall behind if you don't really understand something because everything is cumulative. I would have liked a bit of diversity in class activities. We did almost every exercise in the textbook, but that was about all we did during class. The course description said we'd be learning about Japanese culture and language with components of anime and film and lessons about culture but there wasn't very much of that. I would have liked to watch/read/incorporate some outside sources from the textbook.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the extensive writing exercises were very useful. The group projects were a good way of building class comradery during the pandemic.
Asynchronous days helped much with alleviating stress

This class was the most engaging class of my semester, just because you had to always be participating actively. The in-person class time was used efficiently, though a weakness of zoom is that it's hard to ask for help once you're in a breakout room, which wouldn't be an issue if you were in a classroom.
I think breakout rooms worked very well.

This course (and L1 before it) was the best catered to zoom of all the courses I've taken during the pandemic. This was the best use of breakout rooms I've experienced, making us practice grammar in different groups every day. However, it was very repetitive in activities (different grammar, but I mean we always did just textbook practice). Watching videos or reading texts (other than those in the textbook) could have made it more engaging.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, definitely. The organization of the course is very well organized.
Yes! If you are interested in learning Japanese, Yale has a great Japanese program that will help you build a strong foundation.
Yes. The course and the professor were excellent.
Yes! I loved this class, Yamaguchi sensei is an amazing teacher and very kind
Yes, it's a language course that's well taught so that its not too challenging or too much work for the students.
yes! very interesting and engaging, learned a lot, language skills greatly improved

Yes! If you're serious about wanting to continue your Japanese studies, definitely take this class. I had so much fun in L1, and L2 was a great continuation. You learn a ton and the level of work that you are able to complete by the end of the semester is incredibly rewarding.

Yes. I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in expanding on their skills in Japanese. The workload is high, but if you study the material presented to you the class will be very enjoyable.
Absolutely! Very effectively taught language course, and a very well written textbook with lots of examples and easy to follow grammar explanations.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments:
1. virtual seminar that mostly included class exercises (main room) and partner exercises (breakout rooms)
2. japanese clinic sections with one TA and one student partner
3. optional weekly japanese office hours with TA and professor
Professor Yamaguchi utilized both prerecorded lessons and live discussion to better facilitate student learning.
N/A
group projects instead of live class occassionally
Asynchronous assignment Wednesdays
In-person seminar, recorded class material, weekly tutorial/clinic with a TA
There were live virtual lectures with breakout rooms.
Short recorded daily grammar videos, asynchronous activities (sometimes group work), four times a week live classes for speaking practice
